content.description:
Shared start with Hillbilly Braille climbs face past one bolt to horizontal, then vertical hand crack up to a ledge. Climb pedestal on the ledge to left and right facing corners. Here Hillbilly Braille splits left toward two bolts. Go right, up a hand crack to two bolts protecting a thin, right-facing corner and the small roof. Climb steeply above the roof with good pro in horizontal cracks.

Start marked with a single bolt. The right-most route to climb to the top of the cranberry wall.
single rack to .3 to 3, with optional doubles in .4 - .75. Extendable runners highly recommended on the bolts.

The Ballpark Boulder has three, possibly more climbs on it. They are short, but really fun. From left to right there is an off-width chimney climb that is crazy fun. To the right of that is a bizarre double crack climb, where one crack is a lot more slippery than it may appear at first, and the right-most crack is seriously beautiful and takes fantastic hand jams. Climb it again and again!

Standard trad rack.

Thin crack climbing leads to blocky scrambling.  Some love it, some are unenthused.

Left of Shark Fin. Climbs up towards a broken left-facing dihedral. 
gear from small nuts and 0's to 2". Two bolt anchor, walk off or rap shark fin.

Start in a right-leaning hand crack and climb upwards through flakes to a two bolt anchor.
Better as a top rope. Anchors can be accessed by walking up on climbers right.

Rightmost route of the cranberry wall. 3 m right of Sharkfin. 
small rack of cams and nuts, 2 bolt anchor, rap from sharkfin or walk off.

Move through the ledge and onto the face. Tough foot placements and reachy moves.

Further up the canyon from Shark Fin.
6 bolts, anchors at the top.

An alternate start to Protect The Peelers that avoids the steep start. 

This route is mostly bolted but a few 0.3 - 1" cams will protect areas between bolts. 



Starts on a ledge, just right of "Peelers". 2 bolts, then gear to start. 

Small fingers to 1" cams, 10 quick draws, 2 bolt anchor.

Shares start with the Awining before splitting left at a thin bolted traverse.  Fun, varied climbing up the middle of the cranberry wall.

Shares its start with The Awning. 
4 bolts and a single rack to 4"

Fun sport+ route that stops at the midway ledge. Named for its aggressive and possibly unsound opening.

Left of the basalt patch, right of The Awning.
4 Bolts and a stick clip or 0.4/0.5 BD cam to protect the start

Start on a fun rail deadpoint up to the right on decent features. Tricky foot placements lead to easier climbing and a good rest. From there traverse left and lunge for a good finger crack. More foot trickery unlocks the moves for getting around a large block. Scramble up the block and work through a 5.9 finger crack move to the arrete. Climb the arrete and enjoy the exposure and view. The last mantle is made easier if you locate the pocket to place your foot in.

This route is just up canyon from shark fin. You will notice the bolt line on your right as you walk up the canyon. It starts on the rail above large broken blocks. You can rappel down off of the ring with a 60 meter rope.

8 bolts protect this route. Scrambling up the block is runout. It is possible to protect this with a 2 BD cam. Otherwise just run it out. chain anchors.

Shark Fin follows a right leaning crack with good gear placements and good rests. Then it zigzags up to a horizontal crack. Head right to the fist-sized crack. No feet make for a committing move into the crack, but after that it's straightforward to the top.

2min walk up from Ballpark Boulder, on the right. There are a lot of large flakes/boulders at the bottom of the climb.
Gear to 3", anchors at the top.

Start by working your way up the small corner. Some creativity may be required, there are holds in the corner and higher on the left face. Clip the second bolt from a stable stance on a small shelf. Continue up to the crux which uses a left handed side pull in conjunction with smearing. You can approach it as a balance problem by heading straight up, or use a powerful right layback. The crux is well protected by three bolts in rapid succession. From the top of the crux, use the flake to your right to gain the large shelf. Don't crank on it too hard, it's attached but may not hold up to abuse. Clip the next bolt from the shelf, and look up and left to find a wide horizontal hold just out of reach. Once you've grabbed it, find a way to mantle on top of it. From here head up the remaining large blocks. There are many opportunities for hand and fist jams, but if you look around there are a large number of right handed side pulls available as well. Located in between Shark Fin and Yellow Brick road. The straight line of bolts is clearly visible from the ground, and includes three bolts bunched up near the crux. 8 bolts. Fixed top anchor with two rappel rings is shared with 'Yellow Brick Road'. Stick clip the first bolt using the taped stick found nearby.

This route can be climbed on top rope by first leading 'Yellow Brick Road'.

Shares start with The Awning, but traverses right at the roof through big flakes. 

Shares start with the Awning and Hillbilly Braille.
Gear to 3"

A balancey start leads you up the initial slab. Cut hard left and work your way up fun broken blocks. Undercling a bulge and work right to use a rail above and mantle to the ledge. Get past the crux using a high right foot and search for the hidden right hand hold. Keep moving right and finish up on a nice ledge for clipping the anchors. Rappel and repeat. PS if preparing this route for top rope make sure to use directionals for the second to prevent a pendulum. Just left of shark fin. Same wall. 6 bolts, Fixed anchor at the top with rappel ring. Stick clipping the first bolt is recommended. Look for the stick with tape on it.

The top anchor for this route is located a ways to the right of the beginning. This means that it requires some effort to clean the draws while on rappel. The simplest way is to have somebody clean them while seconding.

If you are top roping, it is suggested that you leave the second to last draw clipped. This while keep the climber from facing a swing during the first half of the climb.
